content.webTitle: Timothy Castagne: 'Rodgers has given me the confidence to go faster'

fields.headline: Timothy Castagne: 'Rodgers has given me the confidence to go faster'
fields.bodyText: Even before his debut against West Brom last Sunday, Timothy Castagne impressed his new teammates at Leicester with a rendition of Jason Mraz’s hit I’m Yours. Those players were glad he was theirs when the right-back, a £21.5m recruit from Atalanta, opened the scoring at the Hawthorns en route to a 3-0 win. “I have to try and continue on that path and don’t stop after just one game,” says a player for whom the cliche “hit the ground running” could have been invented. Running is one of the things the Belgian does best, his dynamism and intensity a quality that makes him so well suited to his name – Castagne happens to be slang for fight in French, his mother tongue – and also to Leicester’s high-energy style. Funnily enough, Thomas Meunier, the Borussia Dortmund player with whom Castagne competes for the right-back slot in his national team, started out at the same club as Castagne, Royal Excelsior Virton, a quirk that gets Castagne wondering. “It is in a small province and you don’t have a lot of players coming out of there,” he says. “But the mentality of the region is always about working hard and keeping running, and that fits a bit the role of full-backs.” That mentality and his ability made him an ideal recruit three years ago for Atalanta, where he took a while to establish himself before becoming part of the side that took Italy and Europe by storm last season, finishing third in Serie A and reaching the quarter-finals of the Champions League. The player says Atalanta’s success was partly due to their determination to bring a small measure of joy to Bergamo, which was particularly hard hit by coronavirus, and also to the running the team did during lockdown. “It was a tough time for everyone there, especially in the city,” he says, adding that the one positive of that grim time was that he and his teammates could work out even more. “We received a treadmill and had to run every day. So we arrived [after lockdown] a lot more prepared than the other teams, that is why after 60 minutes we would kill other teams.” When Leicester came calling, he had several reasons for welcoming the move. One was a yearning nurtured in childhood, when the appeal of the Premier League owed a lot to a glorious striker at Arsenal. “I’ve always loved Thierry Henry, he has been my idol since I was a young boy,” says the 24-year-old, who will fulfil a dream of playing against Arsenal if picked for Wednesday’s Carabao Cup tie at the King Power. He has already worked with Henry, who, says Castagne, did not disappoint during a stint as Belgium’s assistant manager. “I didn’t tell him that he was my hero but it was very good working with him. He was really nice, he wanted to be friends with the players.” The prospect of working with Brendan Rodgers was another factor that lured Castagne to Leicester. Rodgers tried to sign the Belgian when he was manager of Celtic and kept an eye on him ever since. “I wanted a coach with whom I can have a relationship,” he says. “We can talk, he can help me work on my weaknesses and things like that. That’s why I chose to come here because I had a really good impression of him.” Atalanta’s manager, Gian Piero Gasperini, did not offer that. “He wouldn’t speak to anyone,” says Castagne. “He was very good tactically and had very good ideas but we just didn’t have that type of relationship. It depends upon the player but for me I need the relationship. “After the game I was asking: ‘How did I do? What did I do well?’ either to the assistant or the head coach, that would have helped with my confidence but I didn’t get that at Atalanta. Now I’m receiving it and it has been very good.” So what weaknesses does he think Rodgers can help him strengthen? “I can go faster in my execution,” he says. “It’s a lot faster here than in Italy, so he’s going to help me with that, to see more quickly where I can play the ball and where it’s not possible. Also defensively, I can be better in one-v-one. That’s something we are also working on.” One of Castagne’s qualities sometimes struck him as a curse: his versatility has led to him being deployed in a host of positions. He would like to settle on one role but Rodgers has told him he should remain adaptable. That will be especially important when Ricardo Pereira returns from injury. “They know I can play left and right in a [back] four or in a [back] three. [Rodgers] said it’s going to be easier if they need to change something tactical and things like that. “For a player, it’s not easy to always switch. But I’ve done it at Atalanta and it’s worked quite well. I can do it, it’s not a problem for me.”
